docs.lead_paragraph: Will chocolate be as intensely craved and taste as richly luscious if it is no longer viewed as a sinful treat, but, quite the contrary, a health food? Indeed, chocolate and cocoa drinks, it turns out, contain an abundant dose of flavonoids, potent antioxidants that have been found most notably in red wine, green tea and fruits and vegetables, and have been associated with a decrease in the risk of coronary heart disease and stroke. With Americans consuming chocolate at the rate of 3.3 billion pounds a year, researchers have taken a keen interest in whether chocolate may also lower risks of heart disease.

headline.main: Chocolate a Health Food? Maybe, but Keep the Aspirin

docs.abstract: Researchers take keen interest in whether chocolate may lower risks of heart disease; find that chocolate and cocoa drinks contain abundant dose of flavanoids, potent antioxidants that have been found most notably in red wine, green tea and fruits and vegetables, and have been associated with decrease in risk of coronary heart disease and stroke; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Janet Grillo eats organic food, does not smoke or drink and keeps abreast of the latest health news. Yet Ms. Grillo, a 41-year-old independent film producer in Los Angeles, cannot remember the last time she had a complete physical exam, probably when her mother took her to a pediatrician. ''If I'm feeling sick, it's echinacea and early to bed. I think part of the reason I never go is because I get a yearly gynecologic exam and mistake that for accounting for all of my key organs,'' Ms. Grillo said. ''I know it doesn't make sense, but who has time? My own health care lags far behind that of my son.''

headline.main: Major Medical Mystery: Why People Avoid Doctors

docs.abstract: Sociologists and medical clinicians seeking to bolster preventive medicine are trying to figure out why so many people are reluctant to see a doctor; public health experts agree that many people who have money, health insurance and access to good medical centers are choosing not to go for checkups; photos; chart (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Deafness is the most common disability present at birth. Every year, 12,000 American babies are born with moderate to severe hearing impairment and another 12,000 are born with lesser degrees of hearing loss. ''A deaf newborn looks and acts like any other baby,'' said Dr. Andrew J. Schuman, adjunct professor of pediatrics at Dartmouth Medical School. There are rarely outward clues and, unless newborns are tested for hearing loss, it is often not detected until the child is 2 or 3 and fails to start talking.

headline.main: Early Detection of Infant Deafness Is Vital

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody column says that unless newborns are tested for hearing loss, it is often not detected until child is 2 or 3, and fails to start talking; says such delays can permanently impair child's ability to learn to speak intelligibly and can result in long-lasting social, emotional and academic difficulties (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Attention deficit disorder is a good thing? Michael Zane, the kinetic founder of the Kryptonite Bike Lock Corporation, believes it is. After fighting what had been diagnosed as depression for most of his life, Mr. Zane was told by a psychiatrist six years ago that the true diagnosis was attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder, known as A.D./H.D., or A.D.D. Mr. Zane was 46 at the time, and the psychiatrist prescribed a combination of Ritalin and Prozac.

headline.main: Making a Plus of the Deficit in A.D.D.

docs.abstract: Increasing number of people, including mental health professionals, suggest that having attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder may explain some people's extraordinary abilities, and may even improve their lives; Michael Zane, founder of Kryptonite Bike Lock Corp, says having ADD has led to his success; he says he finds his considerable energy harnessed, his self-esteem improved; photo (M)
